Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Expectation2: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation2: Requesting a signature upon delivery for moderately valuable items
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was pulling up to the next address on my delivery route. It was Jamie, my best friend, and I could hear the strain in their voice before they even finished saying hello. “Can you talk? I really need someone right now,” Jamie pleaded, voice trembling. I knew what was expected of me as a friend—drop everything, listen, and be there, especially when Jamie was this upset. But as I glanced at the package on the seat beside me, I remembered the instructions: this one needed a signature, no exceptions. The customer had already called twice to confirm the delivery window, and my supervisor had warned me about the importance of securing signatures for valuable items. I felt my chest tighten as Jamie started to explain the fight with their partner, tears audible through the phone. At the same time, I saw the customer waiting at the door, checking their watch impatiently. My mind raced, torn between the urge to comfort my friend and the responsibility to do my job right. I gripped the steering wheel, caught between two worlds, unsure which one needed me more in that moment.
